Class A Objects are the smallest objects we are able to spot. They usually measure no more than a few meters across.
Class B Objects are relatively small, usually ranging from 4m to 7m in radius, approximately.
Class C Objects are about average-sized. Around the 7-10 meter range in radius, these are certainly not the largest objects out there. They are fairly massive nonetheless.
Class D Objects are quite large. Expect them to be no smaller than 12m in radius, and up to 18m. These are very heavy objects to move around.
Class E Objects are proper behemoths. No less than 18m in radius, they don't just look heavy, they are in fact far more massive than it would seem.
This seems to be a non-standard size class. Who knows what it'll look like?

In Sandbox Mode, all parts and features are available from the start.
You are free to play without any constraints, but R&D and Mission Control are unavailable.

In Science Mode, you must gather scientific data to research new technologies.
Funds and Reputation are disabled, and Contracts are not available (previously 'Classic' Career).

In Career Mode, you have to manage all aspects of your space program.
Funds, Reputation and Science are all active, and Contracts are available at Mission Control.

Welcome To the Vehicle Assembly Building!
Vehicle Assembly Tutorial: Selecting a Command Module
Vehicle Assembly Tutorial: All Systems Go!

This brief tutorial will teach you the basics of building a space worthy craft.
You can drag this window around if it gets in the way.
Press 'Next' to continue.

The first step in building a spacecraft is selecting a Command Module to use. The Command Module is where the crew sits and flies the ship from.
To select a Command Mocule, simply double-click on one of the available modules on the selection screen.
Select a Command Module to continue.
Vehicle construction is done by adding parts from the list to the left, onto the building area here. Try grabbing a Solid Booster and dropping it under the command capsule. Press Next when done.
As you can see, parts will snap to nearby attach points. Those are indicated by those glowing spheres that appear whenever a part is dragged. Press next to continue.

Parts are organized in Categories, according to their functions. Each category will hold it's own list of parts. Click on the Structural & Aerodynamics Tab on the top-left corner of the screen. Press Next when done.

Some parts, like Winglets, don't need to be attached onto attach points. They will stick to the surface of any part that can hold them. Try adding a winglet to the Booster you just added. It will stick to wherever the mouse cursor is pointing at. Press Next when you're done.

Now, that one winglet there will probably unbalance the rocket. If there were another winglet on the other side, it would be balanced again. Hold down the Right Mouse Button to pan the camera around the ship. Get it to face the opposite side, and add another Winglet there. Press Next when done.

It is also possible to rotate the parts before placing them. Try attaching a new set of winglets, but before placing them, use the [W],[S],[A],[D],[Q] and [E] keys to rotate it in different directions.
Also, you can hold [Shift] to rotate them in smaller increments, and if you get lost, pressing [Space] will reset the rotation.
Try it now, and press Next when done.

Removing unwanted parts is as simple as grabbing a part from the ship, and dropping it back onto the parts list. If a part cannot attach to the ship, it will become frozen, so you can pick it up later to reposition or delete it. Alternatively, you can press the [Delete] key to eliminate it. Keep in mind that a part that has other parts attached to them will also take them along when you move it. Also mind that frozen parts will not be launched along with the ship.
Try removing the booster you just added. This will also remove the winglets. Press Next when done.

Good rockets are actually a stack of several rocket engines, boosters and fuel tanks. Those are called 'Stages'. As a rocket climbs and accelerates, it jettisons away the spent fuel tanks and boosters, and other engines further up the stack are ignited. Next, we'll go through the basics of building a multi-stage spacecraft.

The main tool for creating multi-stage spacecraft is the Decoupler part. This can be found under the Structural & Aerodynamic category. When a Decoupler is activated, it separates itself from the ship, and takes along whatever is connected to it. Try adding a Stack Decoupler just under the Command Capsule. Press Next when done.

As you may have noticed already, when a part is added to the ship, an icon is also added to the list on the right side of the screen. This list represents the Staging Sequence of your spacecraft. When flying, you will go through this sequence from bottom to top, activating all parts under each numbered tab together. Note also that adding a Decoupler will also add more numbered tabs to the list. This is because Decouplers will split the rocket when activated and all parts above it should be activated later.

If you happen to disagree with the way our engineers have laid out the staging sequence, you can change it by dragging icons up and down. Each icon represents a part, and that part will only be activated when the stage it's under is activated. For now, it's ok to leave the staging sequence as it is.

Now, let's add a Solid Booster just under the Decoupler you've placed. Note that it's icon will be in the stage just below the decoupler's, meaning it will be activated first, then the decoupler, and so on. Press Next when you're done.

We're nearly ready for our first flight now. The last thing we need is to consider what will happen once that engine runs out, and the ground starts getting closer again. We should think of a way to bring the ship down in such a way that it won't have to be dug out of the ground later. So let's add a Parachute to the top of the Command Capsule. Press Next when done.

Note that the parachute's icon was added along with the Command Capsule in the very last stage. This means it will only be activated and deploy after all the other parts of the ship are used up and jettisoned away. Ok, we're ready to test out that ship. Hit the Launch button and head over to the Launch Pad. Good luck!

Welcome to the Kerbal Space Center Launch Facility! This tutorial will brief you on the basics of piloting a spacecraft. If you haven't yet done the Vehicle Assembly Tutorial, it is recommended doing so before going through this one. If you're ready to go, press Next.

Flying a spacecraft is all about being in control of a generally very chaotic situation. As a Pilot, your main flight controls will affect the pitch, roll and yaw of the ship. Let's look at those first. (All the other controls will be locked until they're needed or this tutorial is closed)

Pitch is the angle of the nose of the ship in relation to the horizon. A positive pitch angle means the nose is pointing upward, while a negative pitch angle means the nose is pointing towards the ground. You control the pitch of your ship through these keys:
[W]: Pitch down [S]: Pitch up
Try it now, and notice the pitch indicator on the lower-left side as it moves.

Yaw is the rotation of the ship around it's vertical axis. It is the side-to-side motion of the ship's nose. A positive Yaw angle means the ship's nose is turned to the right, while a negative angle means it's turned to the left. These are the keys that control yaw:
[A]: Yaw left [D]: Yaw Right.
Try it now.

Roll is the rotation of the ship around its longitudinal, or front-to-back axis. It is the motion of leaning, or banking, to the left or right. The roll of your ship is controlled through these keys:
[Q]: Roll left [E]: Roll Right
Try it now.

By controlling Roll, Pitch and Yaw together, you can keep the ship in a controlled, level flight.
Next, let's look at the other flight controls.

The Throttle control affects the output power of the ship's engines. More throttle means more thrust, and therefore, more speed and lifting power. Note that Throttle will only affect engines that CAN be throttled, like Liquid Engines. Solid Boosters don't have any throttle control, and will burn at top capacity until their fuel runs out.
Holding the ship at full throttle over a long period of time can cause the engines to overheat, and will eventually explode if that heat isn't managed.
Throttle is controlled by the following keys:
[Left Shift]: Throttle Up [Left Ctrl]: Throttle Down
Give it a try now.

Throttle, plus Pitch, Roll and Yaw are the main controls you'll need to master for a successful, crash-free flight. Remember that all of these controls have a limited amount of effectiveness, so bigger, heavier ships will probably respond much more sluggishly to the controls than a little small one. It's also good to keep in mind that as stages are separated from the ship, it will become lighter and therefore easier to control.
Next, let's look at the rest of the Flight Controls.

S.A.S stands for Stability Augmentation System, although Kerbal astronauts usually refer to it as Sickness Avoidance Scheme.
Whatever it stands for, what it does is try to stop the ship from spinning around, using the computer-controlled "Auto-Torque Drive Compensatorâ¢" to counteract the rotation of the ship.
The Mk1 Command Pod comes with a free-trial version of the SAS System, which is less powerful than the dedicated S.A.S Module, but is strong enough for a small ship.
The S.A.S. can be activated momentarily by holding down the [F] key, or toggled by pressing the [T] Key.
Give it a try, and notice the SAS Force indicator that pops out of the Command Pod's icon.

Now, let's look at those Indicators that pop out of the icons.
As you learned in the Vehicle Assembly Tutorial (you did do it didn't you?), each part in the ship creates an icon on the stack on the left side of the screen.
These icons not only indicate in which stage the part it belongs to will be activated, but they also display critical information about the parts.
As you've seen, parts like the S.A.S Module will display an SAS Force gauge, and other parts, such as Boosters and Fuel Tanks, will display information as well, like Fuel levels and Temperatures.
Keep and eye on those indicators to ensure a safe, embarrassment-free flight.

R.C.S. stands for Reaction Control System. It uses several small thrusters to help control the ship's orientation and translation.
The R.C.S. can be activated by pressing the [R] Key.
Give it a try, and notice the RCS Led turns on when it's activated.
Mind that for the RCS to work, your ship must have RCS thrusters and fuel tanks installed.

In flight, all the planning you put into the staging sequence of your ship comes into practice.
From launch to the final deployment of the descent parachutes, you will control the activation of the ship's parts by moving into the next stage.
[SPACE]: Launch / Activate Next Stage
Notice the Stage Indicator on the lower-left corner. It shows the currently active stage. Since we haven't launched yet, it's showing the first stage to be activated, and the Stage Light is blinking green, meaning we're ready to go. We're almost done here, you'll be launching in no time.

An important part of flying is knowing how your ship is orientated and where it is going. A good pilot is always aware of the ship's Attitude, as it's called, and its Velocity Vector.
The big round instrument on the lower center of the screen is called the Nav Ball. This device sums up most of the critical information needed for proper, death-free flight.
Here, you see the ship's nose, in relation to the horizon, as well as its heading (compass bearing) and speed.
You also get a green icon that shows where you're going and a purple one that indicated the direction of this Launch Pad. These icons also have their backwards, or retrograde, representations. If the icon has an X in it, that means it's showing the back end of the direction, and you should turn a full 180Â° if you wanted to go towards it.

On the upper part of the screen you have your Altimeter, Vertical Speed and Atmosphere gauges.
The Altimeter will show the distance to the planet's surface at Sea Level. This means the actual surface may be higher up, so watch out for the ground when landing.
Your Vertical Speed gauge shows how fast your altitude is changing. When launching, it's best to keep this gauge pointing up.
The Atmosphere gauge indicates how deep the ship is in the planet's atmosphere. This helps you know if the ship is high enough for orbiting without losing speed to air resistance.

On the upper-left corner is the Mission Elapsed Time (MET) display. It shows the time since the ship's lift-off.
If you hover the mouse over the gauge, you will see the Time Warp control. In-Flight time compression can be very useful in very long missions. Click on the arrows and see how it works.
Mind that the highest Time Warp rates are only accessible when the ship is far enough into space.

These guys on the lower-right corner are the Crew of the ship.
It's generally a good idea to try and keep them alive throughout the flight.
They're not exactly expert astronauts, or even much good at it. Actually they're none too bright, for that matter, so don't rely on them to be able to fly the ship.

When flying, you have a choice between 2 different camera modes. Each mode makes the camera follow the ship in a different manner. The modes are as follows:
Free Camera (default): The camera is free to pan around the ship, regardless of the ship's orientation.
Chase Camera: The camera will try to always look at the ship from behind.
You can cycle through the different camera modes.
[C]: Cycle camera modes
For a vertical rocket launch, the Free Camera Mode is probably your best option.

The Orbital Map view is another useful navigation feature. In it, you can see your ship's position as well as your trajectory and other useful information.
You can access the Orbital Map by pressing the [M] Key.
If you haven't already done so, the next step will take you into the Map View.

In the Map view, you can control the camera much like you would control the main flight camera.
Holding the Right Mouse Button and moving the mouse will rotate the camera, and the Scroll Wheel will zoom in and out.
Here, you can also press [Tab] to have the camera focus on other objects in space.
Mind that while on this view, you cannot control your spacecraft, although Time Warp controls are still active.
The Icons on the map will display more infomation if you hover the mouse over them.
You can close the Map by pressing [M] again, or by moving into the next step of this tutorial.

This concludes our Flight Tutorial.
Hopefully by now you should know enough to be able to pilot a spacecraft.
By closing this window all controls will be unlocked, and you'll be clear to launch.
At any time you may press [Esc] to pause the game. In the Pause Menu you can restart the flight, or go back to the Space Center.
Hit [Space] when ready to launch!
Good Luck!

Asteroids. Awesome to look at and great to have around; not so much when one lands on your house. Today weâre going to learn how to keep that from happening. As anyone who has played Galaxy Intruders for more than ten minutes can tell you, itâs not about firing at where they are, itâs about aiming at where theyâre going to be.

For that, weâre going to walk through a process called rendezvous. Really, really helpful for making spaceships meet out there and eventually dock, so pay attention. The idea is to know how fast something is going and where itâs headed so you can meet at the same place at the same time. Now open your Map View to take a look at some things.

Now, through luck or Dev-ine intervention this particular asteroid here has been captured in an eccentric but stable Kerbin orbit. This is about as lucky as one can get with these bodies, because in reality most of them will just zoom past Kerbin or take a single trip around it before leaving to never return. When choosing your own I recommend you see what there is to choose from in the Tracking Station and track one of your liking, if you don't track it you'll never catch it.

First things first, basic orbital mechanics. If you match your orbit to an objectâs precisely, youâll be moving at the same speed as it is. If youâre closer to the body you're orbiting, in this case Kerbin, than the object you are trying to meet, you will be going faster, and slower if youâre further out.

Knowing this, let's get started, I took the liberty of creating a maneuver node on your orbit and adjusting it for you to have an orbit that gets as close as possible to the asteroid. Actually I'm sure if you fine-tune it thoroughly you can get even closer. I recommend using your mousewheel to scroll when the mouse is over the node modifiers instead of dragging on them, to have better control. You can check how close your encounter will be if you mouse over the same color Intercept nodes that are close to each other.
This is what the intersect icons look like.

When you're happy with your maneuver execute the burn. One final word of warning though, when executing these kind of precision maneuvers try to leave as little deltaV remaining as possible, or the end result could vary greatly from what you had planned. I won't let you go any further if you don't do it close enough.

Good job. Youâre now on a similar but lower orbit to the Asteroid. Keep it targeted and experiment with your maneuver nodes until you have a closest encounter of less than 10 kilometers, then execute the burn and wait til you reach that encounter. This step is actually optional, just keep in mind that the closer your orbit takes you, the less fuel you'll have to use. Anyway, when you're done click Next.

And this is where speed and efficiency is key. Wait until you're about 5 minutes away from your encounter nodes. Right click the velocity meter in your NavBall so it shows your relative velocity to your Target. Youâre roughly moving at the same speed, but the difference will make one of you drift apart. Aim retrograde in this set up and use your boosters or RCS thrusters to lower that velocity to 0.0 m/s. That means that relative to the asteroid, you are no longer moving. If you get out of the map screen you should even have a visual on the target not too far.

Ok, so now you are "not moving" and you're so close to the asteroid you can almost touch it. What you have to do now is aim yourself towards the asteroid, it's the pink round icon in your NavBall, burn a little to get closer and turn yourself retrograde to kill your speed again, take baby steps trying to get a bit closer every time. For small adjustments you can also use RCS translation burns (

And here we are, now all that's left is to grab that rock, but we'll leave it for next time, your head is probably about to explode with new information, so for now just suffice it to say you achieved quite a feat, good bye for now.

Well pilot, you caught up to it but donât pat yourself on the back yet, youâre not even close to done. How about we catch this rock? Right click on the white dome at the top of your ship and arm your grapple.

This modern marvel of technology will grab onto anything that it touches. The boys at the lab had an intern hanging from there for a whole day. Thing didnât even budge. The equipment has limits obviously, so donât expect to catch any asteroids by ramming it into them at full speed. Think stepping on a soda can but one worth a lot of taxpayer money.

And thatâs why weâre going to handle it with care. Now, with your grapple armed, target the asteroid and slowly and carefully use your RCS thrusters to move towards the asteroid. Keep it straight and once youâre close enough, the mechanism will activate on its own and grab this load of valuable and amazing minerals for us. Be patient, this will take some time, but if you rush it and miss you will make matters worse.

There you go, now weâre grabbed onto the asteroid. You can pretty much call it yours now, but to make it really yours you should rename it. Right click it and choose Rename Asteroid to do so. Thereâs something important when it comes to moving asteroids; efficiency. If you think the way youâre grabbing the asteroid doesnât matter, Iâd ask you to get up, grab a bag of groceries and carry it around with your arm fully outstretched at a 90 degree angle from your body, then do the same carrying it as you normally would and tell me if they were both the same.

Your grapple and the thrust of the ship are bound to the same principles, that's why we have a pivot to modify your connection angle and to make aligning to your centre of mass a complete breeze. Right click on the grapple and unlock the pivot. The grapple itself will remain connected but you will be able to independently move your ship and realign it. Go ahead and adjust yourself until you have a better alignment, then lock the pivot again.

Now you're all set to start redirecting your asteroid, whether you want to use it to study materials, make it a mass destruction weapon or create a rocky space station like some pesky mutant; you're going to have to move

While you could start setting up maneuver nodes and burning in order to move that heavy load of yours right now, it would come at a great fuel cost, so it's better to plan a better approach. Open your map, set Kerbin as your target, and find the point where Kerbin's orbit is closest to yours, then set up a maneuver node OPPOSITE to that.

Now try creating a course that will get you back under Kerbin's SOI, sounds simple enough but watch out for two things. First of all, you're carrying a LOT of mass, so before calling it done see if the maneuver is doable in real life. Rule of thumb is, if you're getting more than a 10 minutes estimated burn time you will probably run out of fuel before completing it. Secondly, if it seems like it's impossible getting a return course, right click the maneuver node, along with the close button two more buttons will appear, these are plus or minus one full orbit, so if you don't get it in this lap maybe you will in the next one, or in 100 years, what difference does it make?

That flight plan looks okay, but it seems like you will have to wait for a loooooong time, so I'll leave you to it. My last advice about this is to use all of your piloting skills when actually executing the burn, sometimes it's hard to keep your ship steady when it weights tens of tons. And also, patience, I know this is a long mission, but you must endure, or use time warp, whatever suits you best. That's all for my part, see you on Kerbin.
This is a demo tutorial to test out the tutorial scenario features. Press Next to go to the next page, or wait
This second page is only here to test the state progression system. Tutorial pages can be stepped forward, and also stepped back.
This third page is also only here to test the state progression system. It's very much like the previous one, but it has a button to restart the tutorial.

This Page shows that it's possible to use external events to send the tutorial to any arbitrary state, even ones not in the default sequence. Use this to handle cases where the player strays off the plan.
Note that this page is added with AddState instead of AddPage, because we don't want this page to be part of the normal tutorial sequence.

Welcome to todays lecture on vessel construction. I'm Wernher von Kerman. Whether you want to put a satellite into orbit, fly a transcontinental flight or step onto the very surface of the Mun you're going to need to build yourself a ship.
It should be pretty easy even if you're not a famous rocket scientist like myself.

First part required in any vessel construction is a command module.
This part will either contain a plucky Kerbal crew or an automated pilot mechanism.
Select a command module from the parts list.

Interesting choice!
Not what I would've picked but, after all, you are not a famous Kerbal rocket scientist like me.

If you ever need to move the vessel around the screen you can pick it up by clicking the command pod.
This will allow you to fit more parts beneath the vessel.

Next thing we need is some fuel to burn. Select one of the fuel tanks on the left.
Click once to select it then click again to attach it to the bottom of your ship.
Not too bad. You might just be getting the hang of this!

Hmm. You need to make sure that the fuel tank is connected to the pod.
It will turn green when its in a suitable position.

Now lets add a rocket to the ship! This creates a jet of high energy gas which pushes the vessel along.
Select one from the left and add it underneath the fuel tank.
Looking good. You remind me of a younger, less experienced, considerably less famous version of myself.

Hmm. You need to make sure that the rocket motor tank is connected to the fuel tank.
It will turn green when its in a suitable position.
Some parts are designed to be attached to the surfaces of others. These allow you to build intricate radial structures and attach ever more rockets.

Now attach some radial parts to the vessel.
You can use the two large buttons in the bottom-left of the screen to control how the editor duplicates and snaps surface mounted parts.

Interesting looking ship. Lets hope it goes better than it looks.
If you want to see its weight, lift and thrust distribution you can use the three small buttons in the lower-left.
Last but not least, make sure you assign a name to your vessel by selecting the name box and then save it.

Looks like our time is almost up. I have to go give yet another a science briefing to the worlds media.
I'll unlock the rest of the parts and features for you to play with. You can hit the launch button when you're ready to fly!
Aim for the stars my friend!
Welcome to the Kerbal Space Center Launch Facility! I'm

and I will teach you the basics of piloting a spacecraft. If you haven't yet done the Vehicle Assembly Tutorial, I recommend you do so before going through this one. If you're ready to go, press Next.

Pitch is the angle of the nose of the ship in relation to the horizon. A positive pitch angle means the nose is pointing upward, while a negative pitch angle means the nose is pointing towards the ground. You control the pitch of your ship through these keys:
[

]: Pitch up
Try it now, and notice the pitch indicator on the lower-left side as it moves.

Yaw is the rotation of the ship around it's vertical axis. It is the side-to-side motion of the ship's nose. A positive Yaw angle means the ship's nose is turned to the right, while a negative angle means it's turned to the left. These are the keys that control yaw:
[

Roll is the rotation of the ship around its longitudinal, or front-to-back axis. It is the motion of leaning, or banking, to the left or right. The roll of your ship is controlled through these keys:
[

By controlling Pitch, Yaw and Roll together, you can keep the ship in a controlled, level flight.
Next, let's look at another basic flight control.

The Throttle control affects the output power of the ship's engines. More throttle means more thrust, and therefore, more speed and lifting power. Note that Throttle will only affect engines that CAN be throttled, like Liquid Engines. Solid Boosters don't have any throttle control, and will burn at top capacity until their fuel runs out.
Holding the ship at full throttle over a long period of time can cause the engines to overheat, and will eventually explode if that heat isn't managed.
Throttle is controlled by the following keys:
[

]: Throttle Down
Give it a try now.

S.A.S stands for Stability Augmentation System, although Kerbal astronauts usually refer to it as Sickness Avoidance Scheme.
Whatever it stands for, what it does is try to stop the ship from spinning around, using the computer-controlled "Auto-Torque Drive Compensatorâ¢" technology to counteract the rotation of the ship.
Keep in mind that to use SAS properly, your ship needs to be fitted with an SAS or ASAS module. Otherwise, SAS won't have any effect.
SAS can be activated momentarily by holding down the [
] key, or toggled by pressing the [

] Key.
You can give it a try now, although it probably won't do much until we are actually flying.

R.C.S. stands for Reaction Control System. It consists of small thrusters that help control the ship's orientation and translation.
The R.C.S. can be activated by pressing the [

] Key.
Give it a try, and notice the RCS Led turns on when it's activated.
Mind that for the RCS to do anything, your ship must have RCS thrusters and Monopropellant tanks installed.
R.C.S is particularly useful when you're out in space, as aerodynamic control surfaces tend to not work very well outside the atmosphere.

In flight, all the planning you put into the staging sequence of your ship comes into practice.
From launch to the final deployment of the descent parachutes, you can control the activation of several of the ship's parts by activating stages.
[

]: Launch / Activate Next Stage
Notice the Stage Indicator on the lower-left corner. It shows the currently active stage. Since we haven't launched yet, it's showing the first stage to be activated. I have your staging controls locked for now, so the LED next to the indicator is glowing purple. We're almost done here, you'll be launching in no time.

An important part of flying is knowing how your ship is orientated and where it is going. A good pilot is always aware of the ship's Attitude, as it's called, and its Velocity Vector.
The big round instrument on the lower center of the screen is called the Nav Ball. This device sums up most of the critical information needed for proper, death-free flight.
Here, you see the ship's nose, in relation to the horizon, as well as its heading (compass bearing) and speed.
You also get several icons that indicate things like your current velocity, but we'll have a look at those later.

On the upper part of the screen you have your Altimeter, Vertical Speed and Atmosphere gauges.
The Altimeter will show the distance to the planet's surface at Sea Level. This means the actual surface may be higher up, so watch out for the ground when landing.
Your Vertical Speed gauge shows how fast your altitude is changing. When launching, it's considered best to keep this gauge pointing up.
The Atmosphere gauge indicates how deep the ship is in the planet's atmosphere. This helps you know if the ship is high enough for orbiting without losing speed to air resistance, or judge how effective wings and controls surfaces will be.

These guys on the lower-right corner are the Crew of the ship.
It's generally a good idea to try and keep them alive throughout the flight.
They're not exactly expert astronauts, or even much good at it. Actually they're none too bright, for that matter, so don't rely on them to be able to fly the ship without your help.

This concludes our Flight Tutorial.
Hopefully by now you should know enough to be able to pilot a spacecraft.
When you close this window, all controls will be unlocked, and you'll be clear to launch.
At any time you may press [Esc] to pause the game. In the Pause Menu you can restart the flight, or end this Tutorial and return to the Main Menu.
Hit [Space] when ready to launch!
Good Luck!

Aha!, You're a curious one arent' you? The IVA button over each crewmember's portrait will let you see the ship from his own perspective.
Note that in this mode, your flight UI has less instruments, since most of them can be found in the cockpit itself.
In Internal View, right-clicking will toggle between mouse-look and interact modes, so you can look aroud without having to hold down the right mouse button. Try looking around and clicking on things, the Engineering department says there are many devices in here that actually work. They seemed to be quite proud of that, in fact.
You can also cycle through the POV of other crewmembers using the [

] key.
Return to External View by pressing [

Ah, I see you found the Map View. The map allows you to see the entire known Solar System, and find your position in it. It will also show you a lot more information, but that's a whole other tutorial.
You can toggle the Map by pressing [

], or by returning to one of the other control modes on the bottom left corner.
Close the map to resume our tutorial.

I see you've found the Docking Controls. In this mode, controls behave somewhat differently, to make maneuvering around in orbit easier. However, that is a topic for a whole other tutorial, so let's just go back to the subject at hand for now.
Press the Staging button on the bottom-left corner or hit [
] to return to the Staging Control Mode.

Welcome to the first in a series of scenarios designed to prepare you for flight in and around Kerbin's local system. I'm going to assume you've completed both the Basic Flight tutorial as well as Orbiting 101. If not, you should go do them.
When you're ready to go, hit Continue.

The bread and butter of flights between celestial objects is a Transfer Orbit. In our case, the periapsis of our orbit will be very near to Kerbin, and the Apoapsis will extend to just beyond the Mun's orbit. The same applies to an interplanetary trajectory, just on a much larger scale.
Now, press the
key to go into the Map View, so we can get an overview of Kerbin's local system.

To perform a successful transfer, it needs to take the same amount of time for both you and your target object to reach the same location.
In the case of the Mun, a good reference point is to place your apoapsis roughly 45 degrees ahead of the Mun in its orbit.
Remember, viewed from above, the Mun orbits counterclockwise!

Now, warp time until you're in the correct position, aim yourself prograde, and fire your engines until your apoapsis intercepts the Mun's orbit right around 45 degrees ahead of it. If your trajectory is correct, the orbit line will shift colors, representing a change in which object's gravity is holding onto when you reach that point.
If you don't get it right the first time, just hit the Reset button to go back and try again.
When you're happy with your trajectory, hit Continue.

Excellent! You're now on an intercept trajectory, headed right for the Mun.
Now we must wait until you reach the Mun's Sphere of Influence, and its gravity starts affecting us, instead of Kerbin's.
Warp time until you reach the Mun's SoI to continue. Be careful with your warp speed, though - too fast, and you might miss your intercept entirely!

You now are gravitationally bound to the Mun. Currently, you're on an escape trajectory relative to the it, so wait until periapsis, and then burn retrograde to slow yourself down enough to be captured into an orbit.
If you make a mistake, hit the Reset button.
You've gone out of the Mun's sphere of influence. Hit the Reset button to try again.

Now that you're not on an escape trajectory, try to get yourself into a circular orbit below at least 200,000m.
Remember what you learned in Orbiting 101!

Good work! You're now in orbit around the Mun with a ship fully capable of landing on it, if you're feeling up to the challenge.
In the next tutorial, we'll cover the full procedure of landing on the Mun, then launching back into orbit.
For now though, my work here is done.

Welcome to the Mun! I trust you managed to land your ship alright, but here we are now. I'd like you to examine the ship very carefully, it's a barebones design of a lander, it contains all you will need to land and get back to Kerbin. Okay, now let's get your crew back home!

Before we do that though let's seize this opportunity to do a little moonwalking. Hover your mouse over the picture of your Kerbal and click the EVA button. In this case the ladder is already deployed, but always make sure it is before stepping out or you could be unable to get back in the ship.

Exactly! Climb down that ladder using the S key. Look at you, walking on the Mun. There are a number of things you can do while EVA'ing, first of all, you can walk around with W, A, S, and D, and if you hold down Shift with these same directions you can run. You can press R to toggle the Jetpack control and spacebar to jump. If you right click the Kerbal there are a few other things you can do, I'll leave it to you to find out, when you've had enough and want to go home get back on the ship.

Off we go then. Getting back to Kerbin works very much the same way as getting from Kerbin to the Mun, but it's actually a lot easier because gravity on the Mun is lower, and also there is no atmosphere.

What you have to do now is throttle all the way up and orient your ship towards Kerbin, in this particular case it's around heading 270 degrees. Once you're properly oriented, open your map view and keep burning until your orbit is on a course that will put you inside Kerbin's SOI, it will be indicated by a theoretical orbit in you map. As soon as it happens hit X to cut throttle and not waste any fuel.

That's right, your current trajectory will put you under Kerbin's Sphere of influence, from there, you should already know what to do, but for now let's just wait until we're orbiting Kerbin. You may use time warp at your discretion.

Okay, now you're gravitationally bound to Kerbin, from here it's child's play to get back home, so let's make it interesting, first put yourself in a circulat orbit of less than 300 km radius, remember what you've learned in previous lessons. You are encouraged to use manuever nodes, but it's not a requirement. If you get another Mun encounter ignore it. Also remember to go easy on the timewarp, you may miss your targets if you overdo it.

Good, in this orbit you can even get picky and choose where you want to land, I'll let you choose the landing location, but I'll give you extra points if you manage to land back at the Kerbal Space Center, I hope you took notice of where it is.

WOW! You actually pulled it off! You're some kind of scientist robot ninja from the future or something, congratulations. This concludes this tutorial, you're about ready to take on any mission that comes your way, so go for it.
Good, you didn't get quite there, but close enough, it was a good effort. This concludes this tutorial, I think you're ready to start your own missions, so go for it.
Ugh, this is so frustrating, you were so close! Well, don't feel bad, you can try the tutorial again any time, see you then.
Well...you're on the ground, safe and sound, and that's what matters the most. This concludes this tutorial, I think you're ready to start your own missions, so go for it.
Welcome to the Orbiting 101 training program! I'm

, and I'm going to teach you the basics of orbiting.
I assume you've already done the basic flight tutorials, and are now ready to learn how to get around in space. If you haven't done them, well, I hope you know what you're doing.
Let's get started.

Orbiting is really nothing more than free-falling. The only thing is that as you fall, you're moving so fast forward, you actually miss the ground. Because up here there is no atmosphere to slow you down, you will continue to free-fall endlessly around the planet, without having to use your engines.
We are currently on a low, almost circular orbit around Kerbin. To get a better view of your situation, press the
key to go into the Map View.

This is the Map View. Here, you can see your ship's position and its current trajectory around the planet.
Use the mouse to look around, to see your orbit from various angles. Also, hovering over the icons on the map will display more information about them.
Close the map when you're ready (press the
key again), so we can proceed.

Good, let's get practical now. I trust you already know your basic spacecraft controls... Up here, they're very much the same, only that the lack of an atmosphere makes the ship behave quite a bit differently. Because there is no drag slowing you down, for every input you apply, you'll have to apply an opposite one to come to a stop again.
I'm going to remotely nudge your attitude controls a little. Try to get the ship back under control afterwards.
If you find yourself totally out of control, hit

to toggle the SAS on.
Are you ready?

There! You're in control now. Stop rotation using the Pitch, Yaw and Roll controls.
I suggest you use the NavBall to orient yourself, instead of looking at the ship. The NavBall isn't affected by the camera rotation, so it should be easier to get your bearings through it than by looking at the outside.

Nicely Done!
Attitude control is an essential skill for a spacecraft pilot. Master it, and you'll be well on your way to becoming an expert commander.
You can try this again if you want, or press Next if you're ready to move on.

Ok, now let's have a look at the NavBall. You've probably seen the symbols on it when you were spinning around.
Here's what they mean:
Prograde Vector: It points towards your velocity vector. That is, it points to where you're going.
Retrograde Vector: It points directly away from your velocity.
Prograde Waypoint Vector: It points towards your current Waypoint.
Retrograde Waypoint Vector: It points directly away from your current Waypoint.

Ok!
Now, let's try something a little more involved. Open your map again.

What we want to do now is go through some of the basic maneuvers you'll need to know. Let's try raising your Apoapsis first.
The Apoapsis is the highest point in an orbit, and it's indicated by the node marked [Ap].
The best place to raise your apoapsis is at the Periapsis [Pe] node, which is the lowest point of your orbit. If you hover the mouse over Periapsis node, you'll see that we are going to reach it in a few minutes. Once there, we will face prograde and burn.
Press
to speed up time a little, so we can get there faster.

times faster than normal, we should be there in a few moments.
You can control time warp with the

keys, or click the arrows on the panel on the top left of the screen.
This time, I'll put us back to normal time just before we reach periapsis.
Out of training though, you'll have to warp time down to 1x yourself, so don't go too fast or you might miss your mark.

Ok, we are a few seconds away from Periapsis now. Time to turn prograde and do our burn.
However, instead of closing the map, let's just bring up the NavBall here, so we can see what's happening to our orbit as we accelerate.
To bring up the NavBall on the Map, click the little tab on the bottom-center of the screen, or press the Numpad Period key.

Good. Time to do our burn. Turn the ship to face the Prograde Vector now.
Turn SAS on if you need help maintaining stability.
Remember, the prograde vector looks like this:
Make sure the ship is pointing towards it before accelerating.
Ok, we are now turned prograde. I've engaged SAS for you to keep her steady. Go ahead and throttle up now.

Notice how the opposite side of your orbit starts to rise as you accelerate.
Keep thrusting prograde until your apoapsis altitude reaches about 800,000m.

Ok, cut the throttle now!
Hold

Well Done!
This is how you raise your Apoapsis node.
With orbital maneuvers, pretty much everything you do will affect the opposite side of your orbit. So to raise the highest point (Apoapsis), you thrust forward (or prograde) at the lowest point (Periapsis). Similarly, to raise your Periapsis, you thrust prograde at Apoapsis. We're on our way to the Apoapsis now, so let's do just that.
Press Next when ready, and I'll warp time to get us there quickly.

Ok, we're on our way to the Apoapsis node now. Notice how your ship loses speed as we rise. That's because we're climbing away from the planet, so we lose speed as we go higher, just as you would if you were climbing a hill back here on Kerbin.
The higher you are, the slower your orbit will be. Notice how the Mun's orbital speed is around 540m/s, while yours is far higher.
When we reach Apoapsis, we will burn prograde again, to raise the Periapsis node and circularize our orbit.

Ok, Here we are... Same as before, turn prograde and fire up those engines, and watch the Periapsis rise.
Mind that we are probably turned the other way right now, so the Prograde Vector might not be visible.
Keep burning prograde until the orbit is nearly circular...

Nicely done!
This is how you change the size of your orbit. This maneuver should come in handy on many situations.
Next, we'll look into changing your orbital inclination.
Press Next when ready to proceed.

Your orbital inclination is the angle your orbit makes to Kerbin's Equator. If you've managed to maintain a reasonable amount of control this far, we should still be in a nearly 0Â° inclination orbit. That is, even though we've changed the altitude of our orbit, it still has the same inclination as before.
Changing inclination is done by thrusting in 90Â° angles to your prograde vector, but without changing your pitch relative to the surface.
On our present, nearly equatorial orbit, prograde is due east. That means to increase our inclination, so that our orbit takes us into higher latitudes, we have to burn towards the North.
Let's try that now: Turn the ship to heading 360Â° and open the throttle.

Notice how as you burn North, your orbit starts to tilt up, but the Periapsis and Apoapsis nodes remain mostly the same.
That is because we are accelerating on a completely new direction, so this maneuver doesn't add or take away any energy from the orbit.
Keep accelerating North until your inclination is about 10Â°.

Good! This is how you change your orbital inclination.
For these maneuvers, it's always better to do it in the slowest parts of the orbit, so you don't have to spend as much delta-V to turn your orbit around. That also means inclination changes on larger orbits, such as we are on now, take less fuel than the same inclination change on a lower one.
Also, keep in mind that changing inclination doesn't necessarily mean accelerating to the north or south. It means accelerating on 90Â° headings to your prograde vector, which on our nearly equatorial orbit, also happened to be towards the north.
Next, let's look into the last essential maneuver you'll need to learn: Lowering our orbit.

As you can imagine, lowering your orbit's altitude is very much like raising it, only in reverse.
Because there's no air up here, we can use our main engines to decelerate as well as accelerate, because nothing says we have to be facing some direction or another.
Also, since our orbit is nearly circular, we can just turn retrograde and do our burn at any time now, so let's get to it.
Turn towards the Retrograde Vector and start those engines up again.

Keep burning retrograde until the Periapsis altitude is around 30,000m.
Try getting it as close as possible this time. If you overshoot and get it too low, turn prograde and accelerate again.

That's it! You're now on your way back.
30,000m is low enough to be in the atmosphere, so you are now on a re-entry course to Kerbin. Once we're below 60,000m, the atmosphere will start slowing the ship down, so that it won't have enough velocity to rise back up again.

This is the end of our lesson now. You can continue doing maneuvers on your own, or wait for periapsis and do a reentry and land. Don't forget to decouple the capsule and deploy the parachutes.
See you on the ground!

Hello and welcome to today's lecture on the Kerbal Scientific Method, I am

, scientist extraordinare. This tutorial doesn't really require any previous knowledge, but in order to gather science points you will have to acquaint yourself with almost every aspect of the game, so you should do them all at some point. We are now at the Kerbal Space Center, I'll give you a quick tour, you can hover the mouse over any building to see it's name in the bar at the bottom of the screen.

The large building on the top left closest to the runway is the Space Plane Hangar, here you can build and fly Spaceplanes. The large cubelike structure in the middle is the Vehicle Assembly Building - this is where you will be constructing most of your Spacecraft. It is connected to the launchpad located at the upper right, this is where you can put your creations to test and start new missions, however the Launchpad will only allow vertical launches. Crew management and hiring applications will take place in the Astronaut Complex, which is located next to the flagpole on the left. The facility with the three parabolic antennas is the Tracking Station, through which you can manage, access and observe all active missions.

The large complex at the bottom of the space center is the Research and Development Complex, that main focus of this tutorial. This is where you will make use of the science points your missions award you, and you will gain more parts. Go ahead and click it to see it in action.

Very good! What you see in the middle of the graph paper is the Tech Tree. It shows how far your research has taken Kerbal technology. You don't have much to show right now, because you're not a world class scientist like myself. At least not yet. But I trust you have the potential to achieve great things.

In a typical career game you will start with a few parts and have to earn the rest. For educations sake I've gone ahead and given some data to your scientists, so you should have enough Science to unlock the next node. The amount of Science you have is shown on the top right. Go for it, select the grayed out node and click the blue Research button on the right pane.

Hooray, that's how research is done. You should have noticed new nodes to be researched spawned from the one you just researched, now you are presented with choices. Don't know what to pick next? Don't worry, you can select a node at any time and useful information will be displayed in the right pane. For example what parts it contains, and how much Science is needed to research it.

Now, you're probably thinking to yourself "This is all nice and jolly, but how do I get more science?". You can get more in three ways: Experiments, Situations, and Biomes. Almost anything you'll do will be an experiment, be it Kerbals writing reports during EVAs or observing Mystery Goo. All of these actions can be accessed through the various right click context menus. Just keep in mind that your crew needs to survive the mission for you go get the Science.

Situations, as the name implies, is about getting yourself in particular situations. This could be landing, orbiting, splashing down. Or anything, really. Biomes are surface samples Kerbals can collect on EVAs during their mission. To keep track of your progress, you can access the Science Archives by clicking the yellow button on the upper left. Well, what are you waiting for? Click it!

That's it! In the archives you can see what experiments, situations and biomes you have already collected. This is important, because you see, if you repeat the same experiment multiple times it's scientific value degrades, because you're not learning anything new, mind you, as a result you will not get as much science as you did the first time, until you get practically nothing.

Another outstanding feature of the archives is that you can check what celestial bodies you have already visited and conducted experiments in. You can do so by clicking the icon corresponding to the body that you're interested in. For now, you will only see the records of the research I gave you, but once you start doing your own science, you will be able to check it here.

Well, this is all I can say about science. This is a theoretical class, and I'm sure it will all make a lot more sense when you go out and try it yourself. Remember that science requires curiosity, so go out and experiment. And don't be discouraged if a mission doesn't go quite as planned, if you learn something new, it's not a complete failure. If you're still feeling lost, feel free to try the other tutorials. I must continue my own research now. I'm looking forward to your accomplishments. Show yourself out by using the red button on the upper right when you're done.
